channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: GitLab pipelines and CI for Perl developers
NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Week 301 - Largest Number & Hamming Distance
item.description: Nice use of unit testing and promoting it. A very clean and easy to follow solution. Well done and keep it up.

item.title: Hammering lists
item.description: Specialised number sort in Perl and Python. II simply love the fresh ideas coming from Python. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Hamming Distance and Large Numbers
item.description: No sort just substr and splice. Also the use of __SUB__ for recursive method call. Highly recommended.

item.title: Hamming it Large
item.description: Choice of language for the post is Crystal. Thank you for a detailed discussion, plenty to learn every week from your work.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #301
item.description: Specialised sort used this week by many. It was a treat and first time for me. Thanks for sharing knowledge with us every week.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 301
item.description: Master of Perl one-liner is once again showing the power of Perl with enough discussion to get the message across. Great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 301
item.description: Raku is showing off one more time. Anyone new to Raku, should definitely checkout the post.

item.title: Auld Lang Comparison
item.description: Do you like CPAN? Well everyone but here you see an alternative solution. Smart approach, keep it up great work.

item.title: Hamming Largest
item.description: Ideal week for one-liner in Raku. A very compact yet powerful statement, great work.

item.title: TWC301
item.description: A very compact and creative solutions in Perl. Always a big fan, thanks for your contributions.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 301
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Largest Number" and "Hamming Distance" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 302
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Ones and Zeroes" and "Step by Step". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Day 23: Generic, general random number simulation using the Inverse CDF method in PDL
TPRC 2025 Papercall
item.description: The first deadline for the 2025 TPRC papercall is on January 15th! Get those papers in! Go to tprc.us for more information!

item.title: Day 25: PDL and the James Webb Space Telescope (broadcasting and dimension tricks)
#701 - Happier New Year!
item.description:
Hi there!

Most of you are probably on vacation and will get back to work at the beginning of January. I hope you'll have a better year than 2024 was. We, here in Israel, don't usually have vacation days at this time of the year, but this year the 8 days of Hanukkah started on December 25th. This means the schools are closed, the kids are on vacation and some people also take vacations days. We too had two days off. On Thursday we visited the Dead Sea and on Sunday we went to Tel Aviv. I wrote about our visits in my personal blog in Hungarian. There are some pictures and some auto-translate might also help you with the text. I hope you also do some special things during your vacation time.

You might have seen that a while ago I started to give live online presentations about Rust, Python, and Perl. On that page you can see both the previous presentations and the planned ones. You might notice that in most of the cases the planned events have a guest speaker. That's sort of my new year's resolution. I decided that starting from January I'll invite guest speakers. After all they have a lot more knowledge than I do.

If you are interested in these virtual meetings and would like to get notified about them, join the Code Mavens Meetup group that I use for the registration. There is one directly Perl-related GitLab pipelines and CI for Perl developers still by myself.

The rest of the calendar still has lots of empty spaces for Perl-related presentations. If you are interested to give one, please contact me! It can be a presentation with slides and all the usual stuff, but it can also be a walk-through of some code-base (e.g. showing how something is implemented in a certain Perl module). It can also be something more pair-programming style where you show me how to do something in Perl. e.g. Show me how to build a web application with Mojolicious. OR Show me how to use PDL to do some fancy data-related thing.

Have a good week and a happy new year!
item.dc:subject: editorial
